pageIntro: Here you will find important words from the blockchain world and the Stellar network. Everything is explained in simple terms.
searchHint: The search finds words and explanations.

blockchain.title: Blockchain
blockchain.short: Shared digital ledger – many computers store the same entries.
blockchain.desc: A blockchain is like a digital ledger. Many computers store the same entries, ensuring that no one can secretly alter anything.

wallet.title: Wallet
wallet.short: Digital wallet that manages your keys.
wallet.desc: A wallet is your digital purse. It manages the keys you need to access your account and send transactions. A wallet can be a program, an app, or even just a piece of paper with your private key.

account.title: Account
account.short: A blockchain account can hold assets and send transactions.
account.desc: An account is the location on the blockchain where your assets are stored. An account has a public address that begins with G. Multiple wallets can access the same account if they have the correct key.

addressG.title: G-address
addressG.short: The public main address of a Stellar account (begins with G).
addressG.desc: The G-address is the main address of a Stellar account. It starts with the letter G. You provide it to others so they can send something to you.

publicKey.title: Public key
publicKey.short: Address that you can share; usually the G-address for Stellar.
publicKey.desc: The public key is the address you can share. In Stellar, this is the G-address. Others use it to send you money.

privateKey.title: Secret key
privateKey.short: Password to the account – never share.
privateKey.desc: The secret key is your password for the account. Whoever has this key can move your money. Never share it.

addressFederation.title: Federation address
addressFederation.short: Short address like email points to a G-address.
addressFederation.desc: A federation address looks like an email. Example: name*domain.com. This short address points to a regular G-address. It is easier to remember.

addressMuxed.title: Muxed account
addressMuxed.short: M-address with additional ID – shares a base account.
addressMuxed.desc: An M-address points to an existing Stellar account but has an additional number (ID). This allows, for example, distinguishing several people or departments under the same G-address. Technically, the money still belongs to the main account.

multisig.title: Multi-signature
multisig.short: Important actions require more than a signature.
multisig.desc: Multi-Sig stands for multiple signatures. An important action requires more than one key. For example, you and a second key both need to agree before something can be sent. This makes theft more difficult.

trustline.title: Trustline
trustline.short: Consent to hold a token of a specific issuer.
trustline.desc:
A trustline is like a "yes, I accept this token." By doing so, you indicate that your account is ready to hold a specific token from a specific issuer. Without a trustline, you cannot receive this token.

Example: A trustline is specified as CODE:ISSUER. For EURT from the issuer GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y…, it is EURT:GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y….

token.title: Token
token.short: Digital unit – e.g., money, points, or credit.
token.desc: A token is a digital unit on the blockchain. A token can represent money, points, or credits for a service.

asset.title: Asset
asset.short: Tokens on Stellar are always linked to an issuer.
asset.desc: On Stellar, a token is called an asset. An asset is always linked to an issuer account. For example, an account can issue a Euro token. This Euro token is then an asset.

xlm.title: XLM
xlm.short: Native currency of Stellar for fees and activation.
xlm.desc: XLM is the native currency of Stellar. You need XLM to pay fees and to create a new account.

mainnet.title: Mainnet
mainnet.short: Real Stellar network with actual value.
mainnet.desc: The real Stellar network with actual value. Transactions are final, and fees are paid in genuine XLM.

testnet.title: Testnet
testnet.short: Public training network without real value.
testnet.desc: A public practice network. Tokens have no real value. Ideal for learning and experimenting without risk.

memo.title: Memo
memo.desc: A memo is a small note that you can send along with a transaction. Often, an exchange requires a specific memo so that it knows to whom the money belongs.

transaction.title: Transaction
transaction.short: Action on the blockchain, e.g., payment or trustline.
transaction.desc: A transaction is an action on the blockchain, such as sending money or creating a trustline. A transaction is permanently stored once it is confirmed.

fee.title: Fee
fee.desc: The fee is a very small amount that you pay with each transaction. The fee goes to the network. On Stellar, the fees are very small.

ledger.title: Ledger
ledger.short: Chain of confirmed data and account balances.
ledger.desc: The ledger is the chain of all confirmed data. It shows which accounts own how much and what transactions have occurred. Anyone can check the ledger.

horizon.title: Horizon
horizon.short: API service through which apps communicate with Stellar.
horizon.desc: Horizon is the service through which programs interact with the Stellar Blockchain. Our tool queries Horizon to load account balances and transactions.

anchor.title: Anchor
anchor.short: Company that connects fiat money with Stellar.
anchor.desc: An anchor is a company that connects real money, such as euros or dollars, with Stellar. For example, you give the anchor euros, and in return, you receive a euro token on Stellar.

exchange.title: Stock exchange
exchange.short: Place to buy and sell tokens.
exchange.desc: An exchange is a place where you can buy or sell tokens. Many exchanges require a KYC procedure, which is an identity verification, before you can withdraw money in euros or francs.

dex.title: DEX
dex.short: Decentralized exchange directly on the blockchain.
dex.desc: DEX stands for Decentralized Exchange. Here, people trade directly with each other on the blockchain. There is no single operator. Stellar has a DEX built-in directly.

liquidityPool.title: Liquidity pool
liquidityPool.short: Common pool with two tokens for immediate exchange.
liquidityPool.desc: A liquidity pool is a shared pool containing two tokens. People contribute both tokens into the pool. Others are then allowed to exchange these tokens instantly. The contributors earn small fees in return.

balanceClaimable.title: Claimable balance
balanceClaimable.short: Reserved money that you still need to accept.
balanceClaimable.desc: A Claimable Balance is money that is already reserved for you, but you still need to claim it. Only when you accept it does it go into your account.

protocolUpdate.title: Protocol Update
protocolUpdate.desc: A Protocol Update is an upgrade of the rules in the Stellar network. For example, new features or security changes. All nodes in the network must use the same rules.

soroban.title: Soroban
soroban.desc: Soroban is the smart contract system of Stellar. A smart contract is program code on the blockchain. The code can independently verify rules and trigger actions without the need for a bank in between.

multiSignature.title: Multisignature (Multi-Signature)
multiSignature.short: Multiple signatures required; weights + threshold determine the approval.
multiSignature.desc: In a multi-signature setup, multiple keys must sign before an action becomes valid. Each signer has a weight, and the sum must reach the required threshold. This increases security because a single stolen key is not sufficient.

signer.title: Signatory (Signer)
signer.short: Public key with weight, part of the account configuration.
signer.desc: A signer is a public key that belongs to an account and has a weight. Its signature counts towards the required threshold. Multiple signers can collectively authorize a transaction.

thresholds.title: Thresholds (Thresholds)
thresholds.short: Limits (low/med/high), which determine the necessary weight sum.
thresholds.desc: Thresholds define how many weighted signatures are required for actions: low for simple operations, med for payments, high for critical changes. The sum of the signer weights must reach the respective threshold.

masterWeight.title: Master weight (master_weight)
masterWeight.short: Weight of the master key; determines how strongly the master key is counted.
masterWeight.desc: The master weight is the weight of the main key of an account. A high master weight allows the master key to sign many actions on its own; a low value requires additional signers.

accountConfig.title: Account configuration (Account Configuration)
accountConfig.short: The interplay of signers and thresholds determines the security of the account.
accountConfig.desc: The account configuration specifies which signers exist with what weights and what thresholds apply. Changes to signers or thresholds are critical for security, as they determine how many signatures are required.

horizonHistory.title: Horizon history
horizonHistory.short: Describes how far back the transaction history provided by public Horizon servers goes.
horizonHistory.desc: Public Horizon servers run by the Stellar Development Foundation (mainnet and testnet) expose only a limited transaction history — currently roughly one year. Older data is no longer available from these free endpoints. If you need to go further back, you basically have two options: (1) run your own Horizon node with full history (including History Archives), or (2) use third‑party/paid services that store and serve historical Stellar data long term.
